item.description:
"In life there are certain sores which, like a kind of canker, slowly erode the soul in solitude." --opening line

Considered one of the most important works of modern Iranian literature, The Blind Owl is a haunting tale of loss and spiritual degradation. Replete with potent symbolism and terrifying surrealistic imagery, Sadegh Hedayat's masterpiece details a young man's despair after losing a mysterious lover.  The novel's layered dream-like narrative  structure recalls Edgar Allan Poe's works of fevered imagination. As the narrator gradually drifts into madness, the reader becomes caught in the sandstorm of Hedayat's bleak vision of the human condition.
